tit.e: Rokuyo (6 days of the Buddhist calendar).
Rokuyo (6 days of the Buddhist calendar).
Rokuyo (6 days of the Buddhist calendar).

sen.j: 六曜（ろくよう）は、暦注の一つで、先勝・友引・先負・仏滅・大安・赤口の6種をいう。
sen.e: Rokuyo refers to one of rekichu (various information recorded in the almanac) and has the five kinds such as sakigachi, tomobiki (The day currently believed to pull a friend by superstition), sakimake, butsumetsu, taian (most auspicious day in the six-day Buddhist calendar) and shakko.

Rokuyo refers to one of rekichu (various information recorded in the almanac) and has the six kinds such as sakigachi (The day on which bold actions are supposed to turn out well), tomobiki (The day currently believed to pull a friend by superstition), sakimake (The day on which it is supposed to be better to avoid disputes and hurried actions), butsumetsu (Buddha's death or unlucky day), taian (The most auspicious day in the six-day Buddhist calendar) and shakko (The day of great misfortune).
sen.cmt: 先勝・先負・仏滅・赤口に説明を追加しました。赤口のみは下記のURLでも英訳がありませんでしたので定訳不明です。ご参考→http://kotobank.jp/
sen.e: Rokuyo refers to one of rekichu (various information recorded in the almanac) and has the six kinds such as sakigachi (The day on which bold actions are supposed to turn out well), tomobiki (The day currently believed to pull a friend by superstition), sakimake (The day on which it is supposed to be better to avoid disputes and hurried actions), butsumetsu (Buddha's death or unlucky day), taian (The most auspicious day in the six-day Buddhist calendar) and shakko (The day of great misfortune).

sen.j: 日本では、暦の中でも有名な暦注の一つで、一般のカレンダーや手帳にも記載されている。
sen.e: In Japan rokuyo is one of famous annotations for the calendar and is described in common calendars or notebooks.
In Japan, rokuyo is one of the most famous rekichu for the calendar and is written in ordinary calendars and notebooks.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正し、単語を訂正しました。
sen.e: In Japan, rokuyo is one of the most famous rekichu for the calendar and is written in ordinary calendars and notebooks.

sen.j: 今日の日本においても影響力が強く、結婚式は大安がよい、葬式は友引を避けるなど、主に冠婚葬祭などの儀式と結びついて使用されている。
sen.e: Now in Japan rokuyo has a strong influence mainly on ceremonial occasions in that it is better to have a wedding on taian and to avoid a funeral on tomobiki and so on.
Now in Japan, rokuyo has a strong influence mainly on ceremonial occasions, for example, it is better to have a wedding on taian and to avoid a funeral on tomobiki.
sen.cmt: 言い回しを修正しました。
sen.e: Now in Japan, rokuyo has a strong influence mainly on ceremonial occasions, for example, it is better to have a wedding on taian and to avoid a funeral on tomobiki.

sen.j: 六輝（ろっき）や宿曜（すくよう）ともいうが、これは七曜との混同を避けるために、明治以後に作られた名称である。
sen.e: It is also called rokki or sukuyo (astrology), but they were named after Meiji era to avoid confusion with shichiyoreki (calendar of the seven luminaries).
sen.cmt: 「七曜」を「七曜暦」と取りました。
sen.e: It is also called rokki or sukuyo (astrology), but these are the names created after the Meiji period to avoid confusion with shichiyoreki (calendar of the seven luminaries).
sen.cmt: 明治時代の訳を修正しました。言い回しを修正しました。
sen.e: It is also called rokki or sukuyo (astrology), but these are the names created after the Meiji period to avoid confusion with shichiyoreki (calendar of the seven luminaries).

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 六曜は中国で生まれたとされるが、いつの時代から暦として確立されたかについては全く不詳である。
sen.e: Rokuyo is said to have been born in China, but it is totally unknown from when it was established as a calendar.
Rokuyo is said to have been born in China, but it is totally unknown when it was established as a calendar.
sen.cmt: 自然な訳になるように修正しました。
sen.e: Rokuyo is said to have been born in China, but it is totally unknown when it was established as a calendar.

sen.j: 孔明六曜星とも呼ばれ、諸葛亮が発案し、六曜を用いて軍略を立てていたとの俗説があるが、三国時代 (中国)から六曜があったということは疑わしく、後世のこじつけであるとするのが定説となっている。
sen.e: It is also called Komei rokuyo star and was invented by Zhuge Liang, who, a popular belief says, made a strategy using rokuyo, but it is doubtful that there has been rokuyo since Three Kingdoms period (of Chinese history) and according to an established theory, it is a far-fetched story in future generations.

It is also called Komei rokuyo star and was invented by Zhuge Liang, who, a popular belief says, made strategies using rokuyo, but it is doubtful that there existed rokuyo in the Three Kingdoms period (of Chinese history) and according to an established theory, it is a far-fetched story created by after generations.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正し、言い回しを修正しました。
sen.e: It is also called Komei rokuyo star and was invented by Zhuge Liang, who, a popular belief says, made strategies using rokuyo, but it is doubtful that there existed rokuyo in the Three Kingdoms period (of Chinese history) and according to an established theory, it is a far-fetched story created by after generations.

sen.j: また一説には、唐の李淳風の作であるともいうが、これも真偽不詳である。
sen.e: And one theory says that it was made by Ri junho during Tang dynasty, but it is also uncertain.
And one theory says that it was made by Ri junho during the Tang dynasty, but it is also uncertain.
And one theory says that it was made by Ri junho during the Tang dynasty, but it is also uncertain.

sen.j: 六曜は元々は、1箇月 (暦)（≒30日）を5等分して6日を一定の周期とし（30÷5 6）、それぞれの日を星毎に区別する為の単位として使われた。
sen.e: Rokuyo was originally used as a unit for distinguishing each day by stars, where one month (calendar) (≒30 days) was divided into five equal parts and six days were regarded as a certain cycle (30÷5= 6).
Rokuyo was originally used as a unit for distinguishing each day by stars, where one month (calendar) (≒30 days) was divided into five equal parts and six days were regarded as a cycle (30÷5= 6).
sen.cmt: certainは不必要ですので削除しました。
sen.e: Rokuyo was originally used as a unit for distinguishing each day by stars, where one month (calendar) (≒30 days) was divided into five equal parts and six days were regarded as a cycle (30÷5= 6).

sen.j: 七曜や旬 (単位)のような使い方がされていたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered to have been used like shichiyo or shun (one of three equal parts in a month) (unit).
sen.cmt: 「旬」を、one of three equal parts in a monthとしました。
sen.e: It is considered to have been used like shichiyo or shun (one of three equal parts in a month) (unit).
It is considered to have been used like shichiyo or shun (one of three equal parts in a month) (unit).

sen.j: 六曜が中国から日本に伝来したのは、14世紀の鎌倉時代末期から室町時代にかけて、とされる。
sen.e: It is considered to be from the end of Kamakura period to Muromachi period that rokuyo was introduced from China to Japan.
It is considered to be from the end of the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period that rokuyo was introduced from China to Japan.
It is considered to be from the end of the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period that rokuyo was introduced from China to Japan.

sen.j: その名称や解釈・順序も少しずつ変えられ、現在では赤口以外は全て名称が変わっている。
sen.e: The name, interpretation and order have been bit by bit changed and now all the names, except for shakko, have been changed.
The name, interpretation and order have been bit by bit changed and now all the names, except for shakko, have been changed.
The name, interpretation and order have been bit by bit changed and now all the names, except for shakko, have been changed.

sen.j: 19世紀初頭の文化年間に現在の形になった。
sen.e: Rokuyo became its present form during the early nineteenth century.
sen.cmt: 「文化年間」は、和暦のため、省略しました。
sen.e: Rokuyo became its present form during the early nineteenth century.
Rokuyo became its present form during the early nineteenth century.

sen.j: 幕末頃から、民間の暦にひっそりと記載され始めた。
sen.e: It began to be secretly described in a folk calendar from the end of Edo period.
It began to be secretly described in a folk calendar from the end of the Edo period.
It began to be secretly described in a folk calendar from the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 明治時代に入って、吉凶付きの暦注は迷信であるとして政府に禁止されたとき、六曜だけは迷信の類ではないと引き続き記載された。
sen.e: During Meiji period rekichu with its fortune was regarded as a superstition and banned by the government, but only rokuyo was considered not to be a kind of superstition and was continuously described.

During the Meiji period, rekichu with fortune was regarded as a superstition and banned by the government, but only rokuyo was considered not to be a kind of superstition and continued to be described.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正しました。冠詞を追加しました。
sen.e: During the Meiji period, rekichu with fortune was regarded as a superstition and banned by the government, but only rokuyo was considered not to be a kind of superstition and continued to be described.

sen.j: このことからかえって人気に拍車をかけることとなり、第二次世界大戦後の爆発的流行に至った。
sen.e: For this reason, it became even more popular and led to a runaway trend after the World War II.
For this reason, it became even more popular and led to a runaway trend after the World War II.
For this reason, it became even more popular and led to a runaway trend after the World War II.

sen.j: 多種多様な暦注のなかでは新顔ながら、現代の日本に広まった。
sen.e: Among various rekichu it was a new one, but it spread across present Japan.
Among various rekichu, it was a new one, but it spread across modern Japan.
sen.cmt: 「現代」の訳を修正しました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: Among various rekichu, it was a new one, but it spread across modern Japan.

sen.j: 各六曜には、固有の吉凶・運勢が定められている。
sen.e: The characteristic fortunes or the good and bad omens are set for each rokuyo.
The unique fortunes and the good or bad omens are assigned to each rokuyo.
sen.cmt: 「固有の」と「定められている」の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: The unique fortunes and the good or bad omens are assigned to each rokuyo.

sen.j: 勝負事に関する内容が多く、「ゲン（元または験）を担ぐ」ことから、元々は賭場の遊び人や勝負師などの間で用いられ出したものではないかと考えられている。
sen.e: Many of them are concerning games and because of 'taking charge of gen (元 or 験)' it is thought to have originally begun to be used among playboys or gamblers in a gambling parlor.
They are thought to have originally begun to be used among prowlers or gamblers in gambling parlors because many of them are concerned with games and these people 'believed in omens'.
sen.cmt: 「ゲン（元または験）を担ぐ」の部分の訳をご確認ください。文章の順序を変更しました。「遊び人」の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: They are thought to have originally begun to be used among prowlers or gamblers in gambling parlors because many of them are concerned with games and these people 'believed in omens'.

sen.j: このため、公営競技の予想紙には、現在でも日付欄とともに掲載されている。
sen.e: For this reason, even now it is listed as well as a dateline in a forecast paper for a public athletic sport.
For this reason, even now, they are listed with the dateline in forecast papers for publicly-owned derbies.
sen.cmt: 「公営競技」は競馬や競艇のような賭け事を指していると思いますので、訳を修正しました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: For this reason, even now, they are listed with the dateline in forecast papers for publicly-owned derbies.

sen.j: 一般的なカレンダーなどにはこれまで広く用いられてきたが、行政をはじめとする公共機関が作成するカレンダーでは使用せず、掲載を取り止めるよう行政指導を行っている機関もある。
sen.e: It has been widely used in a common calendar, but has not been used in a calendar made by public institutions like governments and some institutions order them not to list it through administrative guidance.

It has been widely used in ordinary calendars, but has not been used in calendars made by public institutions like government and some public institutions provide administrative guidance to order not to list it.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正しました。自然な訳になるように修正しました。
sen.e: It has been widely used in ordinary calendars, but has not been used in calendars made by public institutions like government and some public institutions provide administrative guidance to order not to list it.

sen.j: 根拠のない迷信であること、無用な混乱を避けるなどの理由により採用しないものである。
sen.e: It is not applied because of a groundless superstition and avoidance of needless confusion and so on.
It is because they are groundless superstitions and to avoid needless confusion.
sen.cmt: 自然な訳になるように修正しました。
sen.e: It is because they are groundless superstitions and to avoid needless confusion.

sen.j: 仏滅や友引という、仏事と関わり合いそうな言葉が多く使われているが、仏教では、釈迦は占いを禁じている。
sen.e: Many words which seem to be associated with butsuji (Buddhist memorial service) are used, such as butsumetsu or tomobiki, but in Buddhism Shaka (Buddha) have banned fortune-telling.
Many words which seem to be associated with butsuji (Buddhist memorial service) are used, such as butsumetsu or tomobiki, but, in Buddhism, Shaka (Buddha) have banned fortune-telling.
sen.cmt: カンマを追加しました。
sen.e: Many words which seem to be associated with butsuji (Buddhist memorial service) are used, such as butsumetsu or tomobiki, but, in Buddhism, Shaka (Buddha) have banned fortune-telling.

sen.j: また、浄土真宗では親鸞が「日の吉凶を選ぶことはよくない」と和讃に於いて説いたため、迷信、俗信一般を否定しており、特にタブーとされている。
sen.e: And in Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), Shinran preached in Wasan (Japanese hymns) that 'it is not good to choose the days' fortune,' and thus in general superstition or popular belief are denied and especially tabooed.

And in Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), Shinran preached in Wasan (Japanese hymns) that 'it is not good to choose the days' fortune,' and thus, in general, superstition or popular belief are denied and especially tabooed.
sen.cmt: カンマを追加しました。
sen.e: And in Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), Shinran preached in Wasan (Japanese hymns) that 'it is not good to choose the days' fortune,' and thus, in general, superstition or popular belief are denied and especially tabooed.

sen.j: このため、仏教とは一切関係無く、仏事と関わり合いそうな言葉が多いのは、全くの当て字に因る。
sen.e: For this reason, the reason why there are many words which have no relation with Buddhism but are related with butsuji is that they are just phonetic equivalents.
Therefore, the reason why there are many words which have no relation with Buddhism but seems to have a relation with butsuji is just phonetic equivalents.
sen.cmt: originalに沿った訳に修正しました。自然な訳になるように修正しました。
sen.e: Therefore, the reason why there are many words which have no relation with Buddhism but seems to have a relation with butsuji is just phonetic equivalents.

sen.j: 一部の人権団体が「六曜のような迷信を信じる事は差別につながる」として、積極的な廃止を求めている。
sen.e: Some of human-rights group aggressively ask for the abolishment of rokuyo, saying 'to believe superstitions like rokuyo leads to discrimination.'
Some of human-rights group aggressively ask for the abolishment of rokuyo, saying 'to believe superstitions like rokuyo leads to discrimination.'
Some of human-rights group aggressively ask for the abolishment of rokuyo, saying 'to believe superstitions like rokuyo leads to discrimination.'

sen.j: 大津市が作成した2005年版職員手帳が六曜を載せていたために、人権団体の抗議を受けて回収され、全て廃棄処分されるという事件も発生した。
sen.e: The accident happened, in which Otsu city made personal day planners for the year 2005 with rokuyo, but they were recalled because of the protestation of human-rights group and were totally discarded.
There was an incident in which Otsu city made personal day planners for the year 2005 with rokuyo, but they were recalled because of the protest from human-rights group and were totally discarded.
sen.cmt: 自然な訳になるように修正しました。
sen.e: There was an incident in which Otsu city made personal day planners for the year 2005 with rokuyo, but they were recalled because of the protest from human-rights group and were totally discarded.

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 六曜は先勝→友引→先負→仏滅→大安→赤口の順で繰り返すが、旧暦の毎月1日の六曜は以下のように固定されている。
sen.e: Rokuyo is repeated in the order of sakigachi => tomobiki => sakimake => butsumetsu => taian => shakko, but the rokuyo of the day 1 of every month in the old lunisolar calendar is fixed in the following.
Rokuyo repeats in the order of sakigachi => tomobiki => sakimake => butsumetsu => taian => shakko, and the rokuyo of the day 1 of every month in the old lunisolar calendar is fixed as follows.
sen.cmt: 言い回しを修正しました。
sen.e: Rokuyo repeats in the order of sakigachi => tomobiki => sakimake => butsumetsu => taian => shakko, and the rokuyo of the day 1 of every month in the old lunisolar calendar is fixed as follows.

sen.j: よって、旧暦では月日により六曜が決まることになる。
sen.e: Thus in the old lunisolar calendar, rokuyo is set by the months.
Thus in the old lunisolar calendar, rokuyo is fixed to the dates and the months.
Thus in the old lunisolar calendar, rokuyo is fixed to the dates and the months.

sen.j: 定義としては、旧暦の月の数字と旧暦の日の数字の和が6の倍数であれば大安となる。
sen.e: As a definition, if the sum of the number of month and the number of day in the old lunisolar calendar are multiples of six, then it is taian.
As a definition, if the sum of the number of month and the number of date in the old lunisolar calendar are multiples of six, then it is taian.
As a definition, if the sum of the number of month and the number of date in the old lunisolar calendar are multiples of six, then it is taian.

sen.j: しかし、新暦のカレンダーの上では、規則正しく循環していたものがある日突然途切れたり、同じ日の六曜が年によって、月によって異なっていたりする。
sen.e: However in New calendar (solar calendar), one day regularly cycling rokuyo suddenly discontinues, or rokuyo on the same day differs depending on the year or month.
But in New calendar (solar calendar), the regularly cycling rokuyo suddenly discontinues one day, or rokuyo on the same date differs depending on the year or month.
sen.cmt: 自然な訳になるように修正し、語順を変更しました。
sen.e: But in New calendar (solar calendar), the regularly cycling rokuyo suddenly discontinues one day, or rokuyo on the same date differs depending on the year or month.

sen.j: このことが神秘的な感じを与え、これも六曜の人気の要因の一つとなっている。
sen.e: This gives a mysterious aura to rokuyo and is one of the reasons for the popularity.
This gives a mysterious aura to rokuyo and is one of the reasons for the popularity.
This gives a mysterious aura to rokuyo and is one of the reasons for the popularity.

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。「について」をaboutにしました。

sen.j: 現在では、先勝、友引、先負、仏滅、大安、赤口、とあるが、前述の通り古くは赤口以外は全て名称が異なっている。
sen.e: At present there are sakigachi, tomobiki, sakimake, butsumetsu, taian and shakko, but formerly, as mentioned before, all the names except for shakko are changed.
At present, there are sakigachi, tomobiki, sakimake, butsumetsu, taian and shakko, but formerly, as mentioned before, all the names except for shakko have been changed.
sen.cmt: カンマを追加しました。
sen.e: At present, there are sakigachi, tomobiki, sakimake, butsumetsu, taian and shakko, but formerly, as mentioned before, all the names except for shakko have been changed.

sen.j: かつては即吉→共引→周吉→虚亡→泰安→赤口（名称については他説有り）の順で繰り返されていた、とされている。
sen.e: Once, rokuyo is said to have been repeated in the order of sokukichi (即吉) => tomobiki (共引)=> shukichi (周吉) => kyomo (虚亡) => taian (泰安) => shakko (as for the names, there are the other theories).
It is said that rokuyo once repeated in the order of sokukichi (即吉) => tomobiki (共引)=> shukichi (周吉) => kyomo (虚亡) => taian (泰安) => shakko (as for the names, there are other theories).
sen.cmt: 自然な訳になるように修正しました。不要なtheを削除しました。
sen.e: It is said that rokuyo once repeated in the order of sokukichi (即吉) => tomobiki (共引)=> shukichi (周吉) => kyomo (虚亡) => taian (泰安) => shakko (as for the names, there are other theories).

sen.j: 各六曜の詳しい説明は以下の通りである。
sen.e: The detailed explanations for each rokuyo are as follows.
The detailed explanations for each rokuyo are as follows.
The detailed explanations for each rokuyo are as follows.

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 「先んずれば即ち勝つ」の意味。
sen.e: It means 'First come, first served.'
It means, 'First come, first served.'
It means, 'First come, first served.'

sen.j: かつては「速喜」「即吉」とも書かれた。
sen.e: Formerly it was written as '速喜' or '即吉.'
Formerly, it was written as '速喜' or '即吉.'
Formerly, it was written as '速喜' or '即吉.'

sen.j: 万事に急ぐことが良いとされる。
sen.e: It is said to be good to hurry up in all respects.
It is said to be good to hurry up in all respects.
It is said to be good to hurry up in all respects.

sen.j: 「午前中は吉、午後二時より六時までは凶」と言われる。
sen.e: It is said 'it is good in the morning, but it is bad from 2 pm to 6 pm.'
It is said, 'it is good in the morning, but it is bad from 2 pm to 6 pm' on sakigachi days.
It is said, 'it is good in the morning, but it is bad from 2 pm to 6 pm' on sakigachi days.

sen.j: 「せんしょう」「せんかち」「さきがち」「さきかち」などと読まれる。
sen.e: It is read as 'sensho,' 'senkachi,' 'sakigachi,' 'sakikachi' and so on.
It is read as 'sensho,' 'senkachi,' 'sakigachi,' 'sakikachi' and so on.
It is read as 'sensho,' 'senkachi,' 'sakigachi,' 'sakikachi' and so on.

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 「凶事に友を引く」の意味。
sen.e: It means 'drawing a friend when in bad.'
It means 'drawing a friend when in bad.'
It means 'drawing a friend when in bad.'

sen.j: かつては「勝負なき日と知るべし」といわれ、勝負事で何事も引分けになる日、つまり「共引」とされており、現在のような意味はなかった。
sen.e: Once it was said that 'the day should be known to end in a stalemate,' and was said to be the day when all the games end in a draw, that is, 'tomobiki' (both sides end in a draw) and it did not have a present-day meaning.

Once it was said that 'the day should be known to end in a stalemate,' and was said to be the day when all the games end in a draw, that is, 'tomobiki' (both sides end in a draw) and it did not have the present-day meaning.

Once it was said that 'the day should be known to end in a stalemate,' and was said to be the day when all the games end in a draw, that is, 'tomobiki' (both sides end in a draw) and it did not have the present-day meaning.

sen.j: 陰陽道で、ある日ある方向に事を行うと災いが友に及ぶとする「友引日」というものがあり、これが六曜の友引と混同されたものと考えられている。
sen.e: In Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements) there was 'the tomobiki day' when, if something was done in one direction one day, harm was brought to a friend, which is thought to have been confused with rokuyo's tomobiki.

In Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), there is 'the tomobiki day' when, if something is done in one direction on the day, a harm will be brought to a friend, which is thought to have been confused with rokuyo's tomobiki.
sen.cmt: 時制を修正し、文法を修正しました。
sen.e: In Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), there is 'the tomobiki day' when, if something is done in one direction on the day, a harm will be brought to a friend, which is thought to have been confused with rokuyo's tomobiki.

sen.j: 「朝は吉、昼は凶、夕は大吉。ただし葬式を忌む」と言われる。
sen.e: It is said that 'the morning is luck, the afternoon is bad and the evening is excellent luck. However, funerals should be avoided.'
It is said that 'the morning is good, the afternoon is bad and the evening is excellent. However, funerals should be avoided' on tomobiki days.
sen.cmt: 吉と大吉の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: It is said that 'the morning is good, the afternoon is bad and the evening is excellent. However, funerals should be avoided' on tomobiki days.

sen.j: 葬式・法事を行うと、友が冥土に引き寄せられる（＝死ぬ）との迷信があり、友引の日は火葬場を休業とする地域もある。
sen.e: There is a superstition that if a funeral or a memorial service (a Buddhist service) are done, a friend is drawn to the other world (= die), and in some areas crematories are closed on tomobiki day.

There is a superstition that if a funeral or a memorial service (a Buddhist service) is done on a tomobiki day, a friend is drawn to the other world (= die), and in some areas crematories are closed on tomobiki days.
sen.cmt: 「友引の日」の訳を補いました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: There is a superstition that if a funeral or a memorial service (a Buddhist service) is done on a tomobiki day, a friend is drawn to the other world (= die), and in some areas crematories are closed on tomobiki days.

sen.j: しかし、六曜は仏教とは関係がないため、友引でも葬儀をする宗派（浄土真宗）がある。
sen.e: However, rokuyo does not have a relation with Buddhism and thus, even on tomobiki day, funerals are done in a religious school (Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism)).
However, rokuyo does not have a relation with Buddhism and thus, even on tomobiki day, funerals are done in a religious school (Jodo Shinshu).
sen.cmt: 重複する説明を修正しました。
sen.e: However, rokuyo does not have a relation with Buddhism and thus, even on tomobiki day, funerals are done in a religious school (Jodo Shinshu).

sen.j: 火葬場での友引休業を廃止する自治体も増えている。
sen.e: The autonomous bodies, which abolish the tomobiki closing of crematories, have increased.
The autonomous bodies, which abolish the tomobiki closing of crematories, have increased.
The autonomous bodies, which abolish the tomobiki closing of crematories, have increased.

sen.j: 逆に慶事については"幸せのお裾分け"という意味で、結婚披露宴の引出物を発送したりする人もいる。
sen.e: As for auspicious occasion, on the contrary, some send Hikidemono gifts of wedding reception banquet in the sense of 'delivering happiness'.
As for auspicious occasion, on the contrary, some send Hikidemono gifts of wedding reception banquet in the sense of 'delivering a share of happiness'.
sen.cmt: 「お裾分け」の訳を補いました。
sen.e: As for auspicious occasion, on the contrary, some send Hikidemono gifts of wedding reception banquet in the sense of 'delivering a share of happiness'.

sen.j: 「ともびき」という読みが一般的となっているが、中国語の「留引」を「ゆういん」と読むことがルーツとなっており、訓読みとなって「ともびき」と当てはめたため、「友を引く」こととは関係がなかった。
sen.e: The reading 'tomobiki' is common, but its root is in the reading 'yuin' of Chinese '留引' and is read in kun-yomi (Japanese reading of character) to be 'tomobiki' and thus had no relation with 'drawing a friend.'

The reading 'tomobiki' has become common, but its root is in '留引' (yuin), a Chinese word meaning 'holding back', whose sound resembles '友引' (yuin) meaning 'drawing a friend' and whose reading in kun-yomi (Japanese reading of character) is 'tomobiki', thus the roots has no relation with 'drawing a friend.'
sen.cmt: 全体的に説明が不足していましたので、大幅に追加しました。
sen.e: The reading 'tomobiki' has become common, but its root is in '留引' (yuin), a Chinese word meaning 'holding back', whose sound resembles '友引' (yuin) meaning 'drawing a friend' and whose reading in kun-yomi (Japanese reading of character) is 'tomobiki', thus the roots has no relation with 'drawing a friend.'

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 「先んずれば即ち負ける」の意味。
sen.e: It means 'First come, first lost.'
It means 'If you come first, you will loose.'
It means 'The first to act is the first to lose.'

sen.j: かつては「小吉」「周吉」と書かれ吉日とされていたが、字面に連られて現在のような解釈がされるようになった。
sen.e: Once it was written as '小吉' and '周吉' and regarded as Kitsujitsu (lucky day), but, with the printing surface, have been interpreted as the present one.

Once it was written as '小吉' and '周吉' and regarded as a Kitsujitsu (lucky day), but, according to the meaning of the Chinese characters used for sakimake, it has been interpreted as the present meaning.
sen.cmt: 字面の訳を修正しました。その他、分かりづらい部分の説明を補いました。
sen.e: Once it was written as '小吉' and '周吉' and regarded as a Kitsujitsu (lucky day), but, according to the meaning of the Chinese characters used for sakimake, it has been interpreted as the present meaning.

sen.j: 万事に平静であることが良いとされ、勝負事や急用は避けるべきとされる。
sen.e: It is considered to be quiet for everything and it should be avoided to do games or be urgent.
It is considered that it is better to keep quiet for everything and it should be avoided to do games or anything urgent on sakimake days.
sen.cmt: 自然な文章になるように修正しました。
sen.e: It is considered that it is better to keep quiet for everything and it should be avoided to do games or anything urgent on sakimake days.

sen.j: 「午前中はわるく、午後はよろしい」ともいう。
sen.e: It is also said 'the morning is bad, the afternoon is good.'
It is also said, 'the morning is bad, the afternoon is good.'
It is also said, 'the morning is bad, the afternoon is good.'

sen.j: 「せんぶ」「せんぷ」「せんまけ」「さきまけ」などと読まれる。
sen.e: It is read as 'senbu,' 'senpu,' 'senmake,' 'sakimake' and so on.
It is also read as 'senbu,' 'senpu,' 'senmake,' 'sakimake.'
It is also read as 'senbu,' 'senpu,' 'senmake,' 'sakimake.'

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 「仏も滅するような大凶日」の意味。
sen.e: It means 'the extremely bad day when even Buddha perishes.'
It means 'the extremely bad day when even Buddha perishes.'
It means 'the extremely bad day when even Buddha perishes.'

sen.j: 元は「空亡」「虚亡」と言っていたが、これを全てが虚しいと解釈して「物滅」と呼ぶようになり、これに近年になって「佛（仏）」の字が当てられたものである。
sen.e: Originally it was called 'kumo' or 'kyomo,' but it was interpreted as emptiness of everything and came to be called 'butsumetsu' and recently the letter '佛(仏)' (butsu) was applied to it.

It was originally called 'kumo' or 'kyomo' (both meaning 'existing as if nothing exists') but was eventually interpreted as emptiness of everything and came to be called '物滅' (death of everything) (butsumetsu) and recently the letter '佛(仏)' (Buddha) (butsu) was applied instead of 物 (things) (butsu).
sen.cmt: その他、分かりづらい部分の説明を補いました。
sen.e: It was originally called 'kumo' or 'kyomo' (both meaning 'existing as if nothing exists') but was eventually interpreted as emptiness of everything and came to be called '物滅' (death of everything) (butsumetsu) and recently the letter '佛(仏)' (Buddha) (butsu) was applied instead of 物 (things) (butsu).

sen.j: この日は六曜の中で最も凶の日とされ、婚礼などの祝儀を忌む習慣がある。
sen.e: The day is thought to be the worst day in rokuyo and gratuities such as wedding and so on are to be avoided on that day as customs.
The day is thought to be the worst day in rokuyo and celebrations like wedding are to be avoided on that day as customs.
sen.cmt: この文の「祝儀」は金品ではなく、祝いの儀式を指していると思います。
sen.e: The day is thought to be the worst day in rokuyo and celebrations like wedding are to be avoided on that day as customs.

sen.j: この日に結婚式を挙げる人は少ない。
sen.e: Few people hold a wedding on that day.
Few people hold a wedding on that day.
Few people hold a wedding on that day.

sen.j: そのため仏滅には料金の割引を行う結婚式場もある。
sen.e: So there are wedding halls which give special rates on butsumetsu days.
So there are wedding halls which give special rates on butsumetsu days.

sen.j: 他の六曜は読みが複数あるが、仏滅は「ぶつめつ」としか読まれない。
sen.e: The other rokuyo have several reading, but butsumetsu is read only as 'butsumetsu.'
The other rokuyo have several readings, but butsumetsu is read only as 'butsumetsu.'
The other rokuyo have several readings, but butsumetsu is read only as 'butsumetsu.'

sen.j: 字面から仏陀（釈迦）が入滅した（亡くなった）日と解釈されることが多いが、上述のように本来は無関係である。
sen.e: It is often interpreted as the day when Buddha entered nirvana because of the printing surface, but it has no relation with it as mentioned before.
It is often regarded as the day when Buddha died because of the meaning of the Chinese characters used for butsumetsu, but it has no relation with Buddhism as mentioned before.
sen.cmt: 「入滅」の訳をdieに修正しました。
sen.e: It is often regarded as the day when Buddha died because of the meaning of the Chinese characters used for butsumetsu, but it has no relation with Buddhism as mentioned before.

sen.j: 釈迦の死んだ日とされる2月15日 (旧暦)が旧暦では必ず仏滅になるのは、偶然そうなっただけである。
sen.e: February 15 is considered to have been the day of Buddha's death (the old lunisolar calendar), but it is accidental that the day is always butsumetsu in the old lunisolar calendar.
February 15 is considered to have been the day of Buddha's death (the old lunisolar calendar), but it is accidental that the day is always butsumetsu in the old lunisolar calendar.
February 15 is considered to have been the day of Buddha's death (the old lunisolar calendar), but it is accidental that the day is always butsumetsu in the old lunisolar calendar.

sen.j: 「何事も遠慮する日、病めば長引く、仏事はよろしい」ともいわれる。
sen.e: It is also said 'it is better to hesitate for everything and when sick it hangs on, but it is good to hold butsuji.'
It is also said 'it is better to refrain from everything and if you get sick, it hangs on, but it is good to hold butsuji' on the day.
sen.cmt: 「遠慮」の訳を修正しました。自然な文章になるように修正しました。
sen.e: It is also said 'it is better to refrain from everything and if you get sick, it hangs on, but it is good to hold butsuji' on the day.

sen.j: また『物滅』として「物が一旦滅び、新たに物事が始まる」とされ、「大安」よりも物事を始めるには良い日との解釈もある。
sen.e: Also, from "butsumetsu" (things collapse), it means 'once things collapse and things newly start,' and some interpret the day is better than 'taian' to start things.
Also, if "物滅" (butsumetsu) is applied, it means 'things (物) collapse (滅) once and things start anew,' and some interpret the day is better than 'taian' to start things.
sen.cmt: 漢字の説明が不足していると思いましたので補いました。
sen.e: Also, if "物滅" (butsumetsu) is applied, it means 'things (物) collapse (滅) once and things start anew,' and some interpret the day is better than 'taian' to start things.

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 「大いに安し」の意味。
sen.e: It means 'very good.'
It means 'very good.'
It means 'very good.'

sen.j: 六曜の中で最も吉の日とされる。
sen.e: It is considered as the best day in rokuyo.
It is considered as the best day in rokuyo.
It is considered as the best day in rokuyo.

sen.j: 何事においても吉、成功しないことはない日とされ、特に婚礼は大安の日に行われることが多い。
sen.e: The day is said to be good for everything and there is no failure on the day and weddings in particular are often done on taian day.
The day is said to be good for everything and there is no failure on the day and weddings in particular are often done on taian days.
The day is said to be good for everything and there is no failure on the day and weddings in particular are often done on taian days.

sen.j: また、内閣組閣も大安の日を選んで行われるという。
sen.e: Also, selecting ministers for the Cabinet is done on taian day.
Also, selecting ministers for the Cabinet is done on taian days.
Also, selecting ministers for the Cabinet is done on taian days.

sen.j: しかし、本来はこの日に何も行うべきではないとする説もある。
sen.e: However, there is a theory that fundamentally nothing should not be done on the day.
However, there is a theory that fundamentally nothing should be done on the day.
However, there is a theory that fundamentally nothing should be done on the day.

sen.j: この点で、キリスト教やユダヤ教における安息日にほぼ相当するといえる。
sen.e: In that sense, it is roughly equivalent to the Sabbath in Christianity or Judaism.
In that sense, it is roughly equivalent to the Sabbath in Christianity or Judaism.
In that sense, it is roughly equivalent to the Sabbath in Christianity or Judaism.

sen.j: 「たいあん」が一般的な読みだが、「だいあん」とも読む。
sen.e: It is commonly read as 'taian,' but is also read as 'daian.'
It is commonly read as 'taian,' but is also read as 'daian.'
It is commonly read as 'taian,' but is also read as 'daian.'

sen.j: かつては「泰安」と書かれたため、「たいあん」の方が本来の読みということになる。
sen.e: As once it was written as '泰安,' the reading 'taian' is an original reading.
As it was once written as '泰安' (taian), the reading 'taian' is the original reading.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正し、泰安の読みを補いました。
sen.e: As it was once written as '泰安' (taian), the reading 'taian' is the original reading.

tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 陰陽道の「赤舌日」という凶日に由来する。
sen.e: It originates from the bad day called 'shakuzetsunichi' in Onmyodo.
It originates from the bad day called 'shakuzetsunichi' in Onmyodo.
It originates from the bad day called 'shakuzetsunichi' in Onmyodo.

sen.j: 六曜の中では唯一名称が変わっていない。
sen.e: It is the only name which has not been changed in rokuyo.
It is the only name which has not been changed in rokuyo.
It is the only name which has not been changed in rokuyo.

sen.j: 午の刻（午前11時ごろから午後1時ごろまで）のみ吉で、それ以外は凶とされる。
sen.e: It is good only during Uma-no-koku (from around 11 am to 1 pm) and except for that, it is said to be bad.
A shakko day is good only during Uma-no-koku (from around 11 am to 1 pm) and except for that, it is said to be bad.
sen.cmt: 主語を明確にしました。
sen.e: A shakko day is good only during Uma-no-koku (from around 11 am to 1 pm) and except for that, it is said to be bad.

sen.j: この日は「赤」という字が付くため、火の元、刃物に気をつける。
sen.e: The day has the letter '赤' (red) and they are careful of fire or edged tools.
Shakko (赤口) has the letter '赤' (red) so that one must be careful of fire or edged tools.
sen.cmt: 漢字の説明を補いました。
sen.e: Shakko (赤口) has the letter '赤' (red) so that one must be careful of fire or edged tools.

sen.j: つまり「死」を連想される物に注意。
sen.e: That is, they are careful of something which is associated with 'death.'
That is, one must be careful of something which is associated with 'death.'
That is, one must be careful of something which is associated with 'death.'

sen.j: 「しゃっこう」「しゃっく」「じゃっく」「じゃっこう」「せきぐち」などと読まれる。
sen.e: It is read as 'shakko,' 'shakku,' 'jakku,' 'jakko,' 'sekiguchi' and so on.
It is also read as 'shakko,' 'shakku,' 'jakku,' 'jakko,' 'sekiguchi.'
sen.cmt: 言い回しを修正しました。
sen.e: It is also read as 'shakko,' 'shakku,' 'jakku,' 'jakko,' 'sekiguchi.'

sen.j: 「万事に用いない悪日、ただし法事、正午だけは良い」と言われる。
sen.e: It is said to be 'a bad day not used for everything, but it is good for a memorial service (a Buddhist service) and is good only during the noon.'
It is said to be 'a bad day to do anything, but it is good for a memorial service (a Buddhist service) and is good only during the noon.'
It is said to be 'a bad day to do anything, but it is good for a memorial service (a Buddhist service) and is good only during the noon.'

tit.e: Rokuyo looked for from the old lunisolar calendar.
Rokuyo calculated from the old lunisolar calendar
tit.cmt: 不要なピリオドを削除しました。「求める」の訳を修正しました。
tit.e: Rokuyo calculated from the old lunisolar calendar

sen.j: 計算のあまりによって「六曜」を求めることができる。
sen.e: Rokuyo' can be sought by the remainder of calculation.
Rokuyo' can be sought by the remainder of calculation.
Rokuyo' can be sought by the remainder of calculation.

sen.j: なお「月」「日」には旧暦をあてる（下記参照）。
sen.e: As for 'month' and 'day,' those of old lunisolar calendar are applied (see the followings).
As for 'month' and 'date,' those of old lunisolar calendar are applied (see the followings).
As for 'month' and 'date,' those of old lunisolar calendar are applied (see the followings).

sen.j: 例：
sen.e: Example:
Example:
Example:

sen.j: 旧正月（1月1日 (旧暦)）：1+12, 2÷60あまり2→先勝
sen.e: The lunar New Year (January 1 (the old calendar)): 1+1=2, 2÷6=0, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.
sen.cmt: 以下の計算式のパターンから推測すると、ここで「1+12」とありますが、「1+1=2」の間違いだと考えられます。また「2÷60」も「2÷6＝0」と考えました。以下同様に、「=」の抜けを加えました。
sen.e: The lunar New Year (January 1 [the old calendar]): 1+1=2, 2÷6=0, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.
The lunar New Year (January 1 [the old calendar]): 1+1=2, 2÷6=0, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.
Old Hinamatsuri (the Doll's Festival) (March 3 (the old calendar)): 3＋3=6, 6÷6=1, the remainder is 0 => taian.
Old Hinamatsuri (the Doll's Festival) (March 3 [the old calendar]): 3＋3=6, 6÷6=1, the remainder is 0 => taian.
Old Hinamatsuri (the Doll's Festival) (March 3 [the old calendar]): 3＋3=6, 6÷6=1, the remainder is 0 => taian.
Old Tango (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was taken place on the fifth of May): (May 5 (the old calendar)): 5＋5=10, 10÷6=1, the remainder is 4 => sakimake.
Old Tango (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was taken place on the fifth of May): (May 5 [the old calendar]): 5＋5=10, 10÷6=1, the remainder is 4 => sakimake.
Old Tango (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was taken place on the fifth of May): (May 5 [the old calendar]): 5＋5=10, 10÷6=1, the remainder is 4 => sakimake.
Old Tanabata (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was taken place on the seventh of July) (July 7 (the old calendar)): 7+7=14, 14÷6=2, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.
Old Tanabata (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was taken place on the seventh of July) (July 7 [the old calendar]): 7+7=14, 14÷6=2, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.
Old Tanabata (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was taken place on the seventh of July) (July 7 [the old calendar]): 7+7=14, 14÷6=2, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.
Jugoya (night of the full moon) (August 15 (the old calendar)): 8+15=23, 23÷6=3, the remainder is 5 => butsumetsu.
Jugoya (night of the full moon) (August 15 [the old calendar]): 8+15=23, 23÷6=3, the remainder is 5 => butsumetsu.
Jugoya (night of the full moon) (August 15 [the old calendar]): 8+15=23, 23÷6=3, the remainder is 5 => butsumetsu.
The thirteenth night (September 13 (the old calendar)): 9+13=22, 22÷6=3, the remainder is 4 => sakimake.
The thirteenth night (September 13 [the old calendar]): 9+13=22, 22÷6=3, the remainder is 4 => sakimake.
The thirteenth night (September 13 [the old calendar]): 9+13=22, 22÷6=3, the remainder is 4 => sakimake.
Old Shichi-go-san (a day of prayer for the healthy growth of young children) (November 15 (the old calendar)): 11+15=26, 26÷6=4, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.
Old Shichi-go-san (a day of prayer for the healthy growth of young children) (November 15 [the old calendar]): 11+15=26, 26÷6=4, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.
Old Shichi-go-san (a day of prayer for the healthy growth of young children) (November 15 [the old calendar]): 11+15=26, 26÷6=4, the remainder is 2 => sakigachi.

sen.j: 明治5年11月9日太政官布告337号（1872年）において「今般改暦之儀別紙詔書写の通り仰せ出され候條、此の旨相達し候事」と太陰暦を太陽暦に改めるにあたって、次のような「改暦詔書写」を掲げている。
sen.e: In Dajokan fukoku (proclamation by the Grand Council of State) No. 337 (1872) on November 9 in 1872, for changing the lunar calendar to the solar calendar, saying 'Now the proposal for kaireki (changing of calendar) is described in the other document and the intention would be delivered,' the following 'imperial edict to change the calendar system' was raised.

In the Dajokan fukoku (proclamation by the Grand Council of State) No. 337 (1872) published on November 9, 1872 at the occasion of changing the lunar calendar to the solar calendar, the following 'imperial edict to change the calendar system' was raised, saying 'Now the proposal for kaireki (changing of calendar) is described in the other document and the intention would be delivered.'
sen.cmt: 自然な文章になるように語順を修正しました。
sen.e: In the Dajokan fukoku (proclamation by the Grand Council of State) No. 337 (1872) published on November 9, 1872 at the occasion of changing the lunar calendar to the solar calendar, the following 'imperial edict to change the calendar system' was raised, saying 'Now the proposal for kaireki (changing of calendar) is described in the other document and the intention would be delivered.'

sen.j: 「朕惟うに我国通行の暦たる、太陰の朔望を以て月を立て太陽の躔度に合す。故に2, 3年間必ず閏月をおかざるを得ず、置閏の前後、時に季節の早晩あり、終に推歩の差を生ずるに至る。殊に中下段に掲る所の如きはおおむね亡誕無稽に属し、人智の開発を妨ぐるもの少しとせず」と論告し、同年11月24日、太政官布告を続いて発し「今般太陽暦御頒布に付、来明治6年限り略暦は歳徳・金神・日の善悪を始め、中下段掲載候不稽の説等増補致候儀一切相成らず候」とあり、これらの布告をもって禁止されたとする主張がある。
sen.e: It argues that 'We have set the old lunisolar calendar as our calendar fitting the position of the sun in the sky. Thus, every two or three year, we have to put a leap month and before and after the intercalation, the gap of climate and time difference happen. Especially the explanations on middle and lower place, most of them belong to faults and largely prevent the development of human intelligence,' and on November 24 in the same year Dajokan fukoku was continuously issued, where it was described 'Now on issuing the solar calendar, the explanation on middle and lower place and the added one will be totally forbidden as well as the day of luck and merit, money god, the good or bad of the day, from 1873,' which, some insist, banned the old lunisolar calendar.
sen.cmt: 「太陽の躔度」を「天空における位置」としました。
sen.e: It argues that 'Our traditional calendar divides a year into 12 months according to the cycle of new moon and full moon and fits it into the position of the sun in the sky. Thus, we have to put a leap month every two or three years and there happens a climate lag before and after the intercalation, which finally causes errors in calculating the travel of celestial body. Especially, most of the annotations (rekichu) on middle and lower part of calendars are absurd and largely prevent the development of human intelligence,' and, on November 24 in the same year, the Dajokan fukoku was again issued and said, 'Now on issuing the solar calendar, the absurd annotations on middle and lower part of calendars will be totally forbidden including the lucky direction, unlucky direction, and the good or bad of the day, from 1873,' which, some insist, banned rokuyo.
sen.cmt: 詔書の部分を全般的に修正しました。ご参考→http://sogyusha.org/saijiki/01_spring/risshun.html「中下段に掲る所の如き」は暦に掲載された六曜等の吉凶を表すものと解釈しました。ご参考→http://www.ndl.go.jp/koyomi/kotoba/02_rokuyo01.html最後の「禁止された」ものは太陰暦ではなく、六曜のことであると解釈しました。単語を修正しました。
sen.e: It argues that 'Our traditional calendar divides a year into 12 months according to the cycle of new moon and full moon and fits it into the position of the sun in the sky. Thus, we have to put a leap month every two or three years and there happens a climate lag before and after the intercalation, which finally causes errors in calculating the travel of celestial body. Especially, most of the annotations (rekichu) on middle and lower part of calendars are absurd and largely prevent the development of human intelligence,' and, on November 24 in the same year, the Dajokan fukoku was again issued and said, 'Now on issuing the solar calendar, the absurd annotations on middle and lower part of calendars will be totally forbidden including the lucky direction, unlucky direction, and the good or bad of the day, from 1873,' which, some insist, banned rokuyo.

sen.j: 吉田兼好や林羅山、新井白蛾、福澤諭吉などが「日の吉凶」を否定することが窺える内容の文章を書き残している。
sen.e: Kenko YOSHIDA, Razan HAYASHI, Hakuga ARAI, Yukichi FUKUZAWA and so on left the articles whose subject was the denial of 'the fortune of the day.'
Kenko YOSHIDA, Razan HAYASHI, Hakuga ARAI, Yukichi FUKUZAWA and so on left the articles whose subject was the denial of 'the fortune of the day.'
